dataModel.name: tasvegVcCode
dataModel.description: Select the appropriate TasVeg condition code and refer to the vegetation community benchmark. Fill all of the relevant benchmark values into the form.

columns.name: numberObserved
columns.description: 2. Record observed number of species for each life form.

columns.description: 1. Record benchmark number of species for each life form.

columns.name: coverPercentObserved
columns.description: 2. Record observed % cover for each life form.

columns.name: coverPercentBenchmark
columns.description: 1. Record benchmark % cover for each life form.

columns.name: present
columns.description: Life forms with benchmark cover of < 10% are considered â€˜presentâ€™ if any specimens are observed Life forms with benchmark cover of â‰¥ 10% are considered â€˜presentâ€™ if the life form occupies at least 10% of benchmark cover.

columns.name: modified
columns.description: (Apply only where life form is â€˜presentâ€™) Life forms with benchmark cover of <10% are considered substantially modified if the life form has either: - <50% of benchmark species diversity; or - no reproductively mature specimens are observed Life forms with benchmark cover of â‰¥ 10% are considered substantially modified if the life form has either: - <50% of benchmark cover; or - < 50% of benchmark species diversity.

defaultRows.lifeform: PS - Prostrate and mat forming shrubs, including cushion plants

dataModel.description: 1. Record benchmark number of life forms.

dataModel.description: 1. Record the % of life forms present (see Understorey Life Forms table).

dataModel.name: lifeformsPresentClass
dataModel.description: 2. Determine the % of life forms assessed as present vs the benchmark.  3. If â‰¥50% of benchmark no. of life forms are present determine the % modified.

dataModel.name: totalWeedCoverPercent
dataModel.description: 1. Record the observed overall % weed cover and place in appropriate weed cover category.

dataModel.name: highThreatWeedCoverPercent
dataModel.description: 2. Estimate the % cover of â€˜high threatâ€™ weed species, record and determine appropriate category.

dataModel.name: weedCoverClass
dataModel.description: 1. Choose the appropriate category for total weed cover.

dataModel.name: highThreatWeedClass
dataModel.description: 2. Choose the appropriate category for the percentage of 'high threat' weeds.

columns.name: speciesRecruited
columns.description: 1. Record each woody species observed in the zone and the total number.

columns.name: recruitmentAdequate
columns.description: 2. Determine if recruitment of each woody species is adequate and record the number of adequately recruiting woody species.

dataModel.name: recruitmentCohorts
dataModel.description: 1. Is there any evidence of woody recruitment? 2. Is vegetation community reliant on episodic events for recruitment? 3. Determine if episodic event has occurred. 4. Determine proportion of woody spp. with adequate recruitment. â€™Cohortâ€™ refers to a group of woody plants established in a single episode (can include suppressed canopy species individuals). Refer to benchmark for clarification.
constraints: No evidence of a recruitment cohort within community - not driven by episodic events
No evidence of a recruitment cohort - driven by episodic events - clear evidence of appropriate episodic event
No evidence of a recruitment cohort - driven by episodic events - no clear evidence of appropriate episodic event
Evidence of >=1 recruitment cohort in >=1 life form - < 30% species with adequate recruitment
Evidence of >=1 recruitment cohort in >=1 life form - 30% - 70% species with adequate recruitment
Evidence of >=1 recruitment cohort in >=1 life form - >= 70% species with adequate recruitment

dataModel.name: recruitmentDiversity
dataModel.description: 4. Determine proportion of woody spp. with adequate recruitment. High diversity defined as â‰¥50% of benchmark woody species diversity.

dataModel.name: organicLitterBenchmarkPercent
dataModel.description: 1. Refer to vegetation community benchmark and record benchmark % litter cover.

dataModel.name: organicLitterObservedPercent
dataModel.description: 2. Determine the % cover of organic litter in the zone and record. Compare to benchmark %.

dataModel.name: organicLitterCoverCategory
dataModel.description: 3. Select the appropriate organic litter cover category.

dataModel.name: organicLitterType
dataModel.description: 4. Determine if organic litter dominated by native or non-native litter.

dataModel.name: logLengthBenchmark
dataModel.description: 1. Refer to vegetation community benchmark and record benchmark log length.

dataModel.name: logLengthObserved
dataModel.description: 2. Record the total length of logs within the zone. Compare to benchmark.

dataModel.name: logLengthCategory
dataModel.description: 3. Select the appropriate large logs category.

dataModel.name: largeLogsPresent
dataModel.description: 4. Determine the presence of 'large logs' in the zone.

map.output: 0 to 20% of the benchmark number of trees/ha
20 to 40% of the benchmark number of trees/ha
40 to 70% of the benchmark number of trees/ha
70 to 100% of the benchmark number of trees/ha

dataModel.name: patchSize
dataModel.description: 1. Determine the size of the patch. Record and assign to a patch size class.

dataModel.name: patchCategory
dataModel.description: 2. Select the appropriate patch size category. If patch >20ha, decide if it is 'significantly disturbed'.
constraints: More than 20 ha, but significantly disturbed
More than 20 ha but not significantly disturbed

columns.name: nativeVegetationPercent
columns.description: 1. Determine and record the % of native vegetation within 3 radii from perimeter of the zone to nearest 20%.

dataModel.name: distanceToCoreArea
dataModel.description: 1. Determine the distance to the nearest core area.

dataModel.name: coreAreaSignificantlyDisturbed
dataModel.description: 2. Determine if core area is significantly disturbed.

items.source:
Large Trees

Large trees are defined by diameter at breast height (dbh) â€“ see benchmark. *Estimate the proportion of an expected healthy canopy cover that is present (ie. not missing due to tree death or decline).

Tree Canopy Cover

Tree canopy cover is defined as those canopy tree species reaching â‰¥80% of mature height â€“ see benchmark description. *Estimate the proportion of an expected healthy canopy cover that is present (ie not missing due to tree death or decline).

Lack of Weeds

â€˜High threatâ€™ weed species are defined as introduced species (including non-indigenous â€˜nativesâ€™) that achieve >5% cover in the zone or those weed species listed as high threat weeds in Tasmania. A list of high threat weeds in Tasmania is provided in the TASVEG Vegetation Condition Assessment manual. **If total weed cover is negligible (<1%) and high threat weed species are present then score â€˜13â€™. The Assessor should determine the threat posed by any weed listed in the zone.

Recruitment

Treat multiple canopy species as a single species. Adequate recruitment of canopy species requires at least 2 cohorts to be present (seedlings <2m and saplings >2m tall) and where canopy cover is less than benchmark, sufficient recruitment to attain benchmark cover over time. Adequate recruitment of other woody species requires observed immature individuals to be at least 10% of number of mature individuals for each species.

columns.title: Woody species recorded in habitat zone (S and taller)

items.source:
Organic Litter

Litter is defined as dead organic material detached from the parent plant, including plant debris, fallen leaves and twigs <10cm.

Logs

Large logs defined as those with diameter â‰¥0.5 of benchmark large tree DBH.

Patch Size

The patch is the area of native vegetation continuous with the assessment area (zone), regardless of EVC, condition or land tenure. Includes adjoining wetlands. It will be 'significantly disturbed' if activities such as grazing, timber harvesting, roading, fuel reduction burning or Phytophthora infestation have occurred. Effectively most patches within fragmented landscapes are significantly disturbed.

Neighbourhood

The neighbourhood score represents the amount and configuration of native vegetation within proximity of the zone being assessed.

columns.source: Is the neighbourhood of the assessed patch significantly disturbed?:

items.source:
Distance to Core Area

A â€˜core areaâ€™ is native vegetation > 50 ha regardless of type, condition or tenure. Includes natural wetlands and lakes, estuaries and rivers. Determine the shortest distance from the edge of the zone being assessed to the edge of the nearest core area and place the vegetation in the appropriate core area distance category.
